articles.title: Anna Thottappilly
articles.contents:
Hello!
I am a rising sixth year PhD candidate at the Charles H. Dyson School of Applied Economics and
Management, Cornell University. I am a development economist
interested in agriculture, nutrition and climate change.
My research focuses on how climate change related factors such as
elevated carbon dioxide in the atmosphere can alter agricultural yield
and has impacts on future nutrition security. My research also involves
trying to characterize Indian agricultural market to help identify
better nutrition interventions.
Outside of research, I am an avid reader of fiction. I am also good
at crochet and love all things beaches.

articles.title: Research
articles.contents:
Working Papers
Identifying
The Income Effect On Nutrition For Agricultural Households: Separability
Of Production And Consumption
I investigate the characterization of the Indian agricultural market
using a panel data of 960 households in Maharashtra state. I find that
production and consumption are separable in the rural agriculture
market. Using a multinomial logistic regression model, I find that
income increase of households improve the nutrition measured as diet
diversity score (ranging from 0 to 10) establishing the link between
from production to consumption preferences. In fact, women of the
households consume an additional food group if the agricultural income
from sale of crops increase by rupees 500. On the other hand, regressing
the diet diversity score on the health variable of the women show no
significant result. This goes to establish that there is no dependence
of labor characteristics on consumption preferences, that is production
is independent of consumption preferences.
CO2
Fertilization: Assessing the Impact of Carbon Dioxide on Agricultural
Yield
In this paper I validate the result that carbon dioxide improves crop
yield under field conditions, which hitherto was only part of controlled
field experiments and crop science studies. Using the nascent remote
sensing atmospheric carbon dioxide from NASA’s Orbiting Carbon
Observatory – 2 and the agricultural yield data obtained from
ICRISAT-TCI I identify that elevated atmospheric carbon dioxide
increases yield of both wheat and rice over the period 2014 – 17 in
India. I make use of the solar induced fluorescence (SIF) to overcome
simultaneity between carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and crop yields,
since carbon dioxide is both absorbed and released by plants in the two
different physiological processes of photosynthesis and respiration. An
increase of one part per million carbon dioxide in the atmosphere raises
rice yield measured in kilograms per hectare by 0.5 percent, and wheat
yield increases by 1.3 percent.
